get.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
get.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: What did you get for Christmas?
We get a lot of junk mail.
I got a few games free when I bought my computer.
We got a letter from Pam this morning.
I got it off my Dad.
get.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to obtain something by finding it, asking for it, or paying for it
get.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: We need to get help quickly!
It would be a good idea to get professional advice.
You may be able to get a grant from the local authority.
He cleared his throat to get our attention.
I want you to get some information for me.
His father managed to get him a job at the local factory.
get.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to bring someone or something back from somewhere
get.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: Run upstairs and get a pillow.
I went back into the office to get a pen.
Shall I go and get the phone book?
She’s just gone to get the kids from school.
I’ll get a towel for you.
get.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: Where did you get that jacket?
It’s a lovely coat, and I managed to get it cheap in the sales.
You can get a decent PC for about £500 now.
Joe’s going to get tickets for all of us.
While you’re out, could you get me some batteries?
He’s just got himself a new van.
I usually get vegetables from the supermarket.
get.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to pay for something for someone else
get.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: My parents always used to get the ‘Daily Telegraph’.
get.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: to receive money for doing work
get.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: Hospital doctors get a minimum of £50,000 a year.
He gets £4 an hour for stacking shelves.
get.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: to receive money when you sell something
get.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: Did you get a good price for it?
You should get a couple of hundred pounds for your old car.
get.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: to start to have a feeling or an idea
get.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: She began to get an uncomfortable feeling that she was being watched.
I got a terrible shock when I saw how ill he looked.
I got the impression that everyone was fed up with us.
She gets a lot of pleasure from her garden.
get.translation[0].definitions[9].defini: to have, do, or experience something
get.translation[0].definitions[9].exampl: I never get time to read these days.
The west of the country gets quite a lot of rain.
We might get the chance to go to America this year.
get.translation[0].definitions[10].examp: I got flu last winter and was in bed for three weeks.
She was worried she might get food poisoning.
get.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: I got 98% in my last maths test.
the person who gets the highest score
get.translation[0].definitions[12].defin: to receive something as a punishment
get.translation[0].definitions[12].examp: He got ten years in prison for his part in the robbery.
get.translation[0].definitions[13].examp: What time will we get there?
We didn’t get home until midnight.
We got to Paris that evening.
get.translation[0].definitions[14].defin: to reach a particular point or stage of something
get.translation[0].definitions[14].examp: I’ve got as far as chapter 5.
I couldn’t wait to get to the end of the book.
Where have you got up to in the story?
It was disappointing to lose, having got this far in the competition.
get.translation[0].definitions[15].examp: We managed to get past the guards.
They shouted at us to get back.
Peter got to his feet (=stood up).
get.translation[0].definitions[16].defin: to make something or someone move to a different place or position, especially with some difficulty
get.translation[0].definitions[16].examp: I couldn’t get the disk out of the computer.
Could you help me get the wardrobe up the stairs?
We must get food and emergency aid into the area as quickly as possible.
get.translation[0].definitions[17].defin: to travel somewhere on a train, bus etc
get.translation[0].definitions[17].examp: You can get a bus to the station.
I got the 9.15 from London to Edinburgh.
get.translation[0].definitions[18].defin: to change to a new feeling, situation, or state
get.translation[0].definitions[18].examp: She soon got bored with the job.
He calmed down as he got older.
Eat your dinner before it gets cold.
It’s getting to be a problem.
get.translation[0].definitions[18].note_: In this meaning, get is used as a linking verb It links the subject of the sentence with an adjective
get.translation[0].definitions[19].defin: to make someone or something change to a new feeling, situation, or state
get.translation[0].definitions[19].examp: Sometimes she gets me so angry!
Don’t get the children too excited.
He was terrified of getting her pregnant.
It took them 15 minutes to get the boat ready.
get.translation[0].definitions[20].defin: used to say that something, especially something bad, happens to someone or something
get.translation[0].definitions[20].examp: I knew I would get shouted at if I was late home.
This is a question we very often get asked.
You might get hurt if you stand there.
Mind the camera doesn’t get broken.
My dad got killed in a car crash.
She got her foot caught in the wire.
get.translation[0].definitions[21].defin: to accidentally make someone or something experience something
get.translation[0].definitions[21].examp: You’re going to get us all killed!
Mind you don’t get yourself burned.
get.translation[0].definitions[22].defin: to do something, or arrange for it to be done
get.translation[0].definitions[22].examp: I need to get the washing machine fixed.
We must get this work finished on time.
get.translation[0].definitions[23].defin: to make something do a particular thing
get.translation[0].definitions[23].examp: I couldn’t get the engine to start.
We got the lawn mower working again eventually.
get.translation[0].definitions[24].defin: to persuade or force someone to do something
get.translation[0].definitions[24].examp: I’ll get Terry to check the wiring for me.
We couldn’t get him to sign the agreement.
In the end, we got the children clearing the playground.
get.translation[0].definitions[25].examp: I don’t think she got the joke.
I don’t get it – it doesn’t make sense.
I still don’t get how she knew about the meeting.
get.translation[0].definitions[25].note_: In this meaning, get is not used in the progressive You say
get.translation[0].definitions[26].defin: to prepare food or a meal
get.translation[0].definitions[26].examp: Shall I get you a sandwich?
get.translation[0].definitions[27].defin: to be able to receive a particular radio signal, television station etc
get.translation[0].definitions[27].examp: Can you get satellite TV here?
get.translation[0].definitions[28].defin: to answer the door or telephone
get.translation[0].definitions[29].examp: The police got him in the end.
get.translation[0].definitions[30].defin: to attack, hurt, or kill someone
get.translation[0].definitions[30].examp: The other gang members threatened to get him if he went to the police.
get.translation[0].definitions[32].defin: if you get someone on the telephone, they answer the telephone when you have made a call, and so you talk to them
get.translation[0].definitions[32].examp: I tried phoning him at work, but I just got his secretary.
get.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Using the passive
Get is not usually used in the passive If you want to use a passive verb, it may be better to use obtain, which is often used in the passive You say
Most of our electricity is obtained from nuclear power
Most of our electricity is got from nuclear power
get.translation[0].note_box[1].sections[: to get something by finding it, asking for it, or paying for it
I’ve been trying to get some information.
She went to the bank to get some money.
obtain
to get something
Maps and guides can be obtained from the tourist office.
The newspaper has obtained a copy of the letter.
acquire
to get something – used about knowledge, skills, or something big or expensive
The course helps older people to acquire computing skills.
He acquired the property in 1985.
inherit
to get someone’s money or property after they die
Jo inherited a lot of money from her mother.
gain
to get something useful or necessary, such as knowledge or experience
I’ve gained a lot of useful experience.
The research helped us gain an insight into how a child’s mind works.
earn
to get something because you deserve it
He had earned a reputation as a peacemaker.
She earned a lot of respect from her colleagues.
get hold of something
to get something that is rare or difficult to find
I’m trying to get hold of a ticket for the game.
lay your hands on something
to get something that you want very much or that you have spent a lot of time looking for
I read every book I could lay my hands on.
get.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: to receive a particular amount of money
get.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: Uganda continues to get about $100 million a year in foreign aid.
The company still gets a good return on its investments.
get.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: to be given or obtain a job or work
get.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: After university, Jonathan tried to get a job in journalism.
They should be getting a lot of work through the Channel Tunnel project.
